Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Three of the witnesses with criminal records who spoke in favor of the legislation said in later interviews the waiting period is not a deterrent to future crime, but rather a barrier for those who have served their sentences.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: spoke in favor of the legislation; said in later interviews

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: At least 14 states have introduced proposals this year focused on restoration of voting rights, according to the Brennan Center for Justice.
Document Sources.Source Justification: according to the Brennan Center for Justice

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: More than 4.6 million people are disenfranchised in the United States because of felony convictions, according to the Sentencing Project, which studies the issue and advocates for restoration of voting rights for former felons.
Document Sources.Source Justification: which studies the issue and advocates for restoration of voting rights for former felons

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: In Nebraska, nearly 18,000 people are unable to vote because of felony convictions, said the Sentencing Project’s director of advocacy, Nicole Porter.
Document Sources.Source Justification: said the Sentencing Project’s director of advocacy, Nicole Porter

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: King, 51, fought addiction for years and spent five years in prison after being convicted of possessing the party drug Ecstasy and theft by deception, ending probation last August.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: fought addiction for years and spent five years in prison after being convicted of possessing the party drug Ecstasy and theft by deception, ending probation last August

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: King works in the HIV/AIDS field and volunteers at various organizations, but said voting is still the most direct way to be involved and became tearful when talking about being unable to vote.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: works in the HIV/AIDS field and volunteers at various organizations

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I felt so hopeless and helpless not being able to have my voice heard in this last election,” King said. “There are a lot of things that were on the ballot here in Nebraska that hit home with a lot of things that I advocate for.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: works in the HIV/AIDS field and volunteers at various organizations

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Restoring voting rights really is an issue where we’ve seen bipartisan momentum,” said Patrick Berry, counsel for the Democracy program at the Brennan Center.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: counsel for the Democracy program at the Brennan Center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: counsel for the Democracy program at the Brennan Center

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Steve Smith of Civic Nebraska, part of a large coalition of groups supporting the measure, said the wait creates a group of taxpayers who can’t choose their representatives.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: of Civic Nebraska
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: part of a large coalition of groups supporting the measure

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “You’re civically dead and you can’t vote for the people who are levying those taxes,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: of Civic Nebraska
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: part of a large coalition of groups supporting the measure

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The bill’s author, Democratic state Sen. Justin Wayne, said he was going door to door in his first election in 2016 and was told by would-be constituents that they could not vote.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Democratic state Sen.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: the bill’s author

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: He has introduced bills multiple times to do away with the wait period, coming close to success in 2017 when a bill passed the Legislature but was vetoed by then-Republican Gov. Pete Ricketts.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Democratic state Sen.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: the bill’s author

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Wayne, who represents parts of Omaha with strong minority populations, said reconnecting people to the voting process is integral to successful reentry.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Democratic state Sen.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: represents parts of Omaha with strong minority populations

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: His bill advanced this past week from a committee to the full Legislature.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Democratic state Sen.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: the bill’s author

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “When people get out of our system, they’ve got to feel engaged in their community, and the number one way for a person to feel engaged in their community is to be able to vote for the leadership of that community,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Democratic state Sen.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: represents parts of Omaha with strong minority populations

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Kathy Wilcot, a member of the University of Nebraska Board of Regents, was the lone dissenter from among the nearly 20 witnesses who spoke on Wayne’s bill.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: member of the University of Nebraska Board of Regents
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: the lone dissenter from among the nearly 20 witnesses who spoke on Wayne’s bill

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Wilcot stressed she was speaking as an individual and not on behalf of the university.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: member of the University of Nebraska Board of Regents
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: the lone dissenter from among the nearly 20 witnesses who spoke on Wayne’s bill

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I do think that hopefully the waiting period reinforces the fact that voting is something very special, and hopefully that will be part of the things that an individual would consider if they’re tempted to break the law again,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: member of the University of Nebraska Board of Regents
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: the lone dissenter from among the nearly 20 witnesses who spoke on Wayne’s bill

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Demetrius Gatson is among the more than 10,000 people in Nebraska who has no right to vote because they haven’t completed their sentences.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: among the more than 10,000 people in Nebraska who has no right to vote because they haven’t completed their sentences

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Since her 2018 release, she has obtained graduate degrees and served in a variety of volunteer roles.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: among the more than 10,000 people in Nebraska who has no right to vote because they haven’t completed their sentences

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Now 48, Gatson has set up her own nonprofit and is executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House, a safe house for women trying to reenter society.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: among the more than 10,000 people in Nebraska who has no right to vote because they haven’t completed their sentences

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: For the people she works with, being able to register to vote provides a sense of acceptance, especially when there are so many barriers on where they can live, jobs they can work and who they can associate with, she said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: among the more than 10,000 people in Nebraska who has no right to vote because they haven’t completed their sentences

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Gatson said there are critical issues she cares about, including education and criminal justice, but said, “I don’t have a say in anything that goes on in my country because I’m a felon.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: among the more than 10,000 people in Nebraska who has no right to vote because they haven’t completed their sentences

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Steven Scott, 33, was paroled in 2015 after serving more than four years on assault and other charges.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: owner of a physical rehabilitation and athletic coaching center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: was paroled in 2015 after serving more than four years on assault and other charges

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: After his release, he was rejected repeatedly for apartments, got a job only because his boss knew him and had his pursuit of an advanced degree derailed after his record came to light.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: owner of a physical rehabilitation and athletic coaching center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: was paroled in 2015 after serving more than four years on assault and other charges

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: He is now married with two small children and owns his own business, a physical rehabilitation and athletic coaching center.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: owner of a physical rehabilitation and athletic coaching center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: was paroled in 2015 after serving more than four years on assault and other charges

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: He also has regained voting rights and cast ballots for Republican candidates in his first elections, including 2020.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: owner of a physical rehabilitation and athletic coaching center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: was paroled in 2015 after serving more than four years on assault and other charges

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: He sees the two-year wait period as one link in a long chain of barriers for those trying to reenter society.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: owner of a physical rehabilitation and athletic coaching center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: was paroled in 2015 after serving more than four years on assault and other charges

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “You can’t harm society by voting,” he said. “You can only help it.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: owner of a physical rehabilitation and athletic coaching center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: was paroled in 2015 after serving more than four years on assault and other charges

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Restoring the voting rights of former felons drew national attention after Florida lawmakers weakened a voter-approved constitutional amendment and after a new election police unit championed by Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis arrested 20 former felons.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: weakened a voter-approved constitutional amendment; championed by Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Several of them said they were confused by the arrests because they had been allowed to register to vote.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: weakened a voter-approved constitutional amendment; championed by Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: An Oregon proposal would allow felons to vote while incarcerated.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: proposal would allow felons to vote while incarcerated

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: A Tennessee bill would automatically restore voting rights once a sentence is completed, except for a small group of crimes.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: bill would automatically restore voting rights once a sentence is completed, except for a small group of crimes

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Texas legislation would restore voting rights to those on probation or parole.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: legislation would restore voting rights to those on probation or parole

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In Minnesota, Democratic Gov. Tim Walz on Friday signed a bill restoring voting rights to convicted felons as soon as they get out of prison.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Democratic Gov. Tim Walz on Friday signed a bill restoring voting rights to convicted felons as soon as they get out of prison

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: A bill moving through the New Mexico Legislature would do the same.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: a bill moving through the New Mexico Legislature would do the same

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The bill that would eliminate the wait would alter a 2005 law.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: the bill that would eliminate the wait would alter a 2005 law

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Before then, felonies in Nebraska brought a lifetime voting ban in most cases.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: the bill that would eliminate the wait would alter a 2005 law

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: At the time Nebraska was in step with other states.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: the bill that would eliminate the wait would alter a 2005 law

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Now, while a few states require wait times for specific offenses or define completion of a sentence as including things such as fines and restitution, Nebraska is alone in requiring a general waiting period beyond imprisonment and release from parole or probation, said Margaret Love, co-founder and director of the Collateral Consequences Resource Center, which keeps a 50-state database on restoration of rights.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: the bill that would eliminate the wait would alter a 2005 law
